City Guides

Argentina's Best Cities for Expats

From the cosmopolitan energy of Buenos Aires to the wine country charm of Mendoza, explore the cities where expats are building their new lives in Argentina.

Buenos Aires

CABA

The Paris of South America. Argentina's pulsating capital offers world-class culture, dining, and nightlife with the largest expat community in the country.

$1,200–$2,500/month
First-time expatsDigital nomadsFoodies+2 more
Explore Buenos Aires

Córdoba

Córdoba

Argentina's university city and emerging tech hub. Young energy, affordable living, and stunning sierras make it the best-value big city in the country.

$600–$1,200/month
Digital nomadsStudentsTech workers+2 more
Explore Córdoba

El Calafate

Santa Cruz

Gateway to the Perito Moreno glacier and Los Glaciares National Park. A Patagonian frontier town where the ice age is still happening in real time.

$800–$1,600/month
Glacier enthusiastsNature photographersTrekkers+2 more
Explore El Calafate

La Plata

Buenos Aires

Argentina's 'planned city' — a perfectly geometric university town just 60 km from Buenos Aires with stunning architecture, student energy, and half the cost of the capital.

$500–$1,000/month
StudentsAcademicsArchitecture lovers+2 more
Explore La Plata

Mar del Plata

Buenos Aires

Argentina's Atlantic beach city — surfing, seafood, and a year-round urban beach lifestyle just 4 hours from Buenos Aires. The 'Happy City' lives up to its name.

$600–$1,300/month
Beach loversSurfersSeafood enthusiasts+2 more
Explore Mar del Plata

Mendoza

Mendoza

Wine country paradise at the foot of the Andes. World-class Malbec, outdoor adventures, and 300 days of sunshine make this South America's answer to Napa Valley.

$700–$1,400/month
Wine enthusiastsOutdoor adventurersRetirees+2 more
Explore Mendoza

Neuquén

Neuquén

Patagonia's oil capital — a modern, prosperous city on the Limay River with gateway access to wine, dinosaurs, and the Andes.

$800–$1,800/month
Energy professionalsPatagonia explorersWine lovers+2 more
Explore Neuquén

Paraná

Entre Ríos

A riverfront gem overlooking the Paraná — Argentina's former capital with tree-lined boulevards, thermal springs, and a slow-living culture.

$500–$1,100/month
Slow-living enthusiastsNature loversRiver fishermen+2 more
Explore Paraná

Posadas

Misiones

Gateway to Iguazú Falls — a subtropical riverside city on the Paraguay border with mangoes, red earth, and mate culture everywhere.

$400–$900/month
Budget expatsNature loversCross-border shoppers+2 more
Explore Posadas

Puerto Madryn

Chubut

Whale watching capital of Argentina. The gateway to Península Valdés where southern right whales, orcas, penguins, and elephant seals congregate in stunning numbers.

$700–$1,400/month
Wildlife enthusiastsMarine biologistsNature photographers+2 more
Explore Puerto Madryn

Rosario

Santa Fe

Argentina's third city — birthplace of the flag, Che Guevara, and Messi. A river city with a growing cosmopolitan scene, great food, and BA vibes at half the price.

$600–$1,200/month
Budget-conscious BA loversRiver lifestyle seekersStudents+2 more
Explore Rosario

Salta

Salta

Salta la Linda — colonial charm, desert landscapes, world-famous empanadas, and the most affordable city living in Argentina. The Northwest's crown jewel.

$500–$1,000/month
Budget expatsCulture loversFood enthusiasts+2 more
Explore Salta

San Carlos de Bariloche

Río Negro

The 'Switzerland of South America.' Crystal-clear lakes, snow-capped peaks, artisan chocolate, and world-class skiing in the heart of Patagonia's Lake District.

$800–$1,600/month
SkiersMountain loversOutdoor adventurers+2 more
Explore San Carlos de Bariloche

San Juan

San Juan

Argentina's sun capital — 300+ cloudless days, world-class Malbec beyond Mendoza, and gateway to the stunning Ischigualasto moonscape.

$500–$1,100/month
Wine loversSun seekersBudget expats+2 more
Explore San Juan

San Martín de los Andes

Neuquén

The quieter Bariloche — a charming Patagonian mountain town on Lago Lácar with world-class skiing, hiking, and fly fishing, minus the tourist crowds.

$800–$1,500/month
Fly fishersSkiersMountain lovers+2 more
Explore San Martín de los Andes

San Miguel de Tucumán

Tucumán

The Garden of the Republic — where Argentine independence was born. Lush, historic, and ultra-affordable with strong university culture and authentic Northwest flavors.

$400–$900/month
Budget expatsHistory enthusiastsStudents+2 more
Explore San Miguel de Tucumán

San Salvador de Jujuy

Jujuy

Gateway to the Quebrada — where Andean culture meets colonial charm at the foot of Argentina's most colorful landscapes.

$350–$800/month
Cultural immersion seekersBudget expatsPhotographers+2 more
Explore San Salvador de Jujuy

Santa Fe

Santa Fe

Argentina's constitutional capital — a university city where colonial heritage meets student energy on the banks of the Salado River.

$500–$1,200/month
StudentsHistory enthusiastsBudget expats+2 more
Explore Santa Fe

Ushuaia

Tierra del Fuego

The End of the World. The planet's southernmost city, gateway to Antarctica, with dramatic mountains, glaciers, and a frontier spirit that defines Patagonia.

$900–$1,800/month
Antarctic enthusiastsExtreme sports loversNature photographers+2 more
Explore Ushuaia

Villa Carlos Paz

Córdoba

Argentina's summer playground — a lakeside resort town in the Sierras with theater culture, outdoor sports, and a vibrant social scene.

$600–$1,400/month
RetireesTheater loversHikers+2 more
Explore Villa Carlos Paz

Head-to-Head City Comparisons

Not sure which city is right for you? See how they stack up side by side.

Buenos Aires vs Mendoza

Capital city energy vs wine country tranquility. Compare Argentina's biggest metropolis with its premier wine region for expat life, cost of living, safety, and lifestyle.

Compare now

Buenos Aires vs Cordoba

Mega-city sophistication vs university-town energy. Compare Argentina's capital with its second city for cost, culture, tech scene, and expat lifestyle.

Compare now

Mendoza vs Bariloche

Wine country vs lake district. Two of Argentina's most stunning regions compared for expat life, outdoor access, cost, and year-round livability.

Compare now

Salta vs Cordoba

Colonial Northwest charm vs central university energy. Compare two affordable Argentine cities for budget expats seeking authentic culture and community.

Compare now

Rosario vs Córdoba

Argentina's second and third cities compared. Industrial port city vs university hub — both affordable, both with strong identities.

Compare now

Ushuaia vs Bariloche

End of the world vs lake district paradise. Compare Argentina's two iconic Patagonian destinations for extreme nature and unique expat experiences.

Compare now

Mar del Plata vs Buenos Aires

Beach city escape vs capital city energy. Compare Argentina's summer capital with its actual capital for year-round expat living.

Compare now
View All Comparisons
